sentence.text: Patient 4 is a white Scottish male from a nonconsanguineous family.
Bilateral talipes equinovarus was noted on antenatal ultrasound.
He was delivered at 41 weeks gestation by elective cesarean section, with a birth weight of 3.77 kg (50th–75th centile).
He first walked at 5 years of age, first words were at 2 years and 6 months of age, and he is not toilet trained.

On assessment at the age of 8 years, he had brachycephaly, a flat face, frontal hair upsweep, highly arched eyebrows, hypertelorism, epicanthic folds, long eyelashes, wide nasal bridge, thin upper lip, and everted lower lip (Figure 1).
His ears were low set and posteriorly rotated, and his tongue had a grooved tip.
His head circumference was between the 25th and 50th centiles and height and weight both between the 50th and 75th centiles.
He had three café au lait patches, and the anus was anteriorly placed.
He had scoliosis and bilateral talipes equinovarus, and also primary generalized epilepsy.
Radiographs demonstrated abnormal modeling and fusion of his ribs, predominantly on the right.
